Now their mission is to "annotate the world".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genius.com/web-annotator/ |publisher=Romi Ezzo|accessdate=2015-12-18}}</ref> *[[GeniusRocket]] is a crowdsourcing [[advertising agency]] that uses an online community of thousands of artists from around the world.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/02/09/super-bowl-ads-and-the-rise-of-the-prize-economy/ |work=The New York Times | first=Steve | last=Lohr | date=2009-02-09 | title=Super Bowl Ads and the Rise of the Prize Economy}}</ref> *GeoTag-X<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geotagx.org/ |publisher=geotagx.org |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> is a crowdsourcing research project set up by [[UNOSAT]] (the United Nations Institute for Training and Research's Operational Satellite Applications Programme) as part of the Citizen Cyberlab<ref>{{cite web|url=http://citizencyberlab.eu/ |publisher=citizen cyberlab |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> project. GeoTag-X aims to help disaster relief efforts on the ground to plan a response by asking volunteers to analyse photos taken in disaster-affected areas. * The Canadian gold mining group [[Goldcorp]] made 400 megabytes of geological survey data on its Red Lake, Ontario, property available to the public over the Internet. They offered a $575,000 prize to anyone who could analyze the data and suggest places where gold could be found. The company claims that the contest produced 110 targets, over 80% of which proved productive; yielding 8 million ounces of gold, worth more than $3 billion. The prize was won by a small consultancy in Perth, Western Australia, called Fractal Graphics. *[[Google Image Labeler]] was a sort of game where users were asked to label pictures in order to improve images search results.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/09/01/google-image-labeler/ | work=techcrunch | first=Michael | last=Arrington | date=2006-09-01 | title=Google Image Labeler Uses Human Labor}}</ref> *[[Google Translate]] [https://translate.google.com/community The Google Translate Community] serves as a way to improve google's translation quality. It allows anyone to volunteer and make the translations better for everyone using google translate. *[[Gooseberry Patch]], has been using crowdsourcing to create their community-style [[cookbooks]] since 1992. Friends, buyers, fans, sales people are all encouraged to submit a recipe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.gooseberrypatch.com/gooseberry/recipe.nsf/v.pages/f.archiveclub |title=Share a Recipe, Craft or Special Memory with Gooseberry Patch |publisher=.gooseberrypatch.com |accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> Each contributors' recipe that is selected is recognized in the book and receives a free copy. *[http://goviralstudy.com GoViral Study] is a crowdsourcing research project that collects fluid specimens from the community and analyzes them with the latest molecular diagnostics instruments. The study examines viral and symptom information from people in one community and examine how this can be used to predict an individual's risk of influenza and other respiratory and gastrointestinal illnesses. A self-collected specimen kit is sent to participants and at any time someone gets sick, they are asked to provide a nasal swab, saliva or fecal sample. The study is being conducted by Dr. Rumi Chunara at New York University, and it is being funded by the National Science Foundation and is part of Open Humans.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://blog.openhumans.org/2015/10/09/be-a-part-of-govirals-third-season/|title = Be a part of GoViral's third season!|first = h|last = k|accessdate = November 6, 2015}}</ref> * The Great War Archive,<ref name="Oucs.ox.ac.uk"/> was a 2008 project led by the [[University of Oxford]] that asked members of the general public to digitise any artefacts they held relating to the [[First World War]] and upload them to a purpose built website. The project successfully released over 6500 items and stories online which can be freely downloaded and used for education and research. The project was funded by the [[Joint Information Systems Committee]]. In 2011, the team at the [[University of Oxford]] received further funding from [[Europeana]] to run a similar crowdsourcing initiative in Germany. From 2012 [[Europeana]] extended this to become a project called "Europeana 1914-1918",<ref name="europeana1918"/> a collaboration led by [[Europeana]] with support from the team at the [[University of Oxford]]. There is a website<ref name="europeana1918"/> where the project encourages the public from all [[European Union]] states to contribute information about [[World War I]], especially their family's stories and digitised photographs of their artefacts.<ref name="pro.europeana.eu"/> * ''[[The Guardian]]'''s investigation into the MP Expense Scandal in the United Kingdom. == H == * herbaria@home<ref>{{cite web|url=http://herbariaunited.org/atHome/|title=herbaria@home project homepage|work=herbarium@home project}}</ref> documents botanical collections in the United Kingdom. * The [[Historical Marker Database]] is an illustrated searchable online catalog of historical information viewed through the filter of roadside and other permanent outdoor markers, monuments, and plaques. * The [[Vancouver Police Department]] has put up a website entitled Hockey Riot 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vancouver.ca/police/2011riot/index.html |title=Hockey Riot 2011 | Vancouver Police Department |publisher=Vancouver.ca |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> informing people about the VPD′s investigations into the [[2011 Vancouver Stanley Cup riot|2011 Stanley Cup Riot]]. It also asks people to contribute any pictures or video that they may have taken during the riot, with the goal of identifying people who may have participated in the rioting. The site also reminds people to not use social media to take justice into their own hands, instead leaving it to the police. As of July 1, 2011, 101 arrests have been made.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://vancouver.ca/police/2011riot/index.html | title = Hockey Riot 2011 | work = | author = Vancouver Police Department | date = June 28, 2011 | accessdate = 2011-07-01}}</ref> * Humanoid is a startup aiming to build an aggregator of crowdsourcing marketplaces (including [[Amazon Mechanical Turk]]), adding a layer of automated workforce management on top of crowdsourced labor. Workers are asked to review each other's work, and bots assign each worker a reputation, automatically rerouting tasks by throwing in errors to test workers and otherwise computing worker fatigue.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schonfeld|first=Erick|title=With Backing From Google Ventures, Humanoid Brings Robot Supervision To Crowdsourced Task|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/11/02/humanoid-google-ventures/|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref>

== N == *[[Netflix prize|Netflix Prize]], was an open competition for the best collaborative filtering algorithm that predicts user ratings for films, based on previous ratings. The competition was held by Netflix, an online DVD-rental service, and was completed in September 2009. The grand prize of $1,000,000 was reserved for the entry which best shows Netflix's own algorithm for predicting ratings by 10%. Netflix provided a training data set of over 100 million ratings that more than 480,000 users gave to nearly 18,000 movies, which is one of the largest real real-life data sets available for research. The related forum maintained by Netflix has seen lively discussions and contributed a lot to the success of this competition. A very relevant fact to the power of crowdsourcing is that among the top teams are not only academic researchers, but laymen with no prior exposure to collaborative filtering (virtually learning the problem space from scratch).
== O == {{see also|open innovation}} *[[Open Food Facts]] gathers information and data on food products from around the world. *[[Old Weather]] is a web-based effort to transcribe weather observations made by Royal Navy ships around the time of World War I. These transcriptions will contribute to climate model projections and improve a database of weather extremes and will be of use to historians in tracking past ship movements and the stories of the people on board.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oldweather.org/about |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101015040847/http://www.oldweather.org/about |archivedate=2010-10-15 |df= }}</ref> * [[OpenSeaMap]] is a free nautical chart covering seas, lakes, inland waterways and rivers for the needs of sailors, divers, fishermen and canoeists. The data is collected by crowdsourcing. In a new project OpenSeaMap collect shallow water depths worldwide for making [[Bathymetry|bathimetric]] charts. * [[OpenSignal]] is a project to independently map cell phone carrier coverage and performance. All data is collected from a smartphone application that has been downloaded over 3.5m times worldwide. * [[OpenStreetMap]] is a free editable map of the world, which has over 100,000 signed up contributors in mid-2009. Creation and maintenance of geospatial data is a labor-intensive task which is expensive using traditional approaches, and crowdsourcing is also being used by commercial companies in this area including Google and TomTom. * [[Oxfam Novib]] (Netherlands) mid-2008 launched a crowdsourcing initiative named Doeners.net, meant for people to support the organization's campaigning activities. * [[Online volunteering]] service (United Nations) is a free service that connects grassroots organizations, international NGOs, local governments, educational institutions and United Nations agencies with thousands of individuals ready to volunteer via the Internet to help address development challenges. The service was launched in 2000 and it quickly attracted thousands of people ready to volunteer online. In 2014 alone, UN Online Volunteers undertook 16,134 assignments.<ref>[https://www.onlinevolunteering.org/en/org/resources/newsletter_april_2015.html Online Volunteering service, Newsletter] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20150613191654/https://www.onlinevolunteering.org/en/org/resources/newsletter_april_2015.html |date=2015-06-13 }}</ref>

== T == * [https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=15ECSnEzlpb7kYJFAkvE02sfzWKAgNt7X] TearDropp is a network across social media which finds, collects and processes the digital footprint for pseudo-live mapping of water activity worldwide [[created and maintained by John Buckovetz]]. Projects include searching for the tomb of Genghis Khan,<ref>{{cite web |title=Map Explorer: Field Expedition: Mongolia |url=http://exploration.nationalgeographic.com |publisher=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |accessdate=2014-03-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311210116/http://exploration.nationalgeographic.com/# |archive-date=2014-03-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> mapping earthquake damage after the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Participate in GEO-CAN Assessment of Christchurch |url=http://www.preisente.de/blog/2011/11/participate-in-geo-can-assessment-of-christchurch/ |publisher=preisente.de |accessdate=2014-11-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217001758/http://www.preisente.de/blog/2011/11/participate-in-geo-can-assessment-of-christchurch/# |archive-date=2014-12-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370|Malaysia Flight 370]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Missing Airplane: Malaysia Airlines MH370 – help us tag! |url=http://www.tomnod.com/nod/challenge/malaysiaairsar2014 |publisher=tomnod.com |accessdate=2014-03-11 }} • {{cite news |title=Crowdsourcing volunteers comb satellite photos for Malaysia Airlines jet |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/11/us/malaysia-airlines-plane-crowdsourcing-search |last1=Martinez |first1=Michael |last2=Newsome |first2=John |publisher=CNN |date=2014-03-11 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0TmRxPs?url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/11/us/malaysia-airlines-plane-crowdsourcing-search |archivedate=2014-03-12 }}</ref> counting refugee camps in Somalia, and the search of the Tunante II. * Torneo de Ideas<ref>{{cite web|url=http://torneodeideas.com |title=torneodeideas.com |publisher=torneodeideas.com |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> is the first Mexican crowdsourcing platform, it is a community whose main objective is to provide creative solutions to the needs of small and middle Hispanic corporations. They currently provide solutions mainly on graphic design and each project or "tournament" receive an average of 150 designs. Torneo de Ideas was winner of the startup contest [[Wayra]] Mexico 2012<ref>{{cite web|author=Čeština |url=http://wayra.org/es/startup/torneo-de-ideas |title=Torneo de Ideas |language=es |publisher=Wayra |accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> and has been mentioned in several entrepreneur publications such as [[Entrepreneur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soyentrepreneur.com/23490-encuentra-ideas-creativas-con-crowdsourcing.html |title=Encuentra ideas creativas con crowdsourcing |publisher=SoyEntrepreneur |date=November 22, 2012 |accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> *[[Transcribe Bentham]] is a crowdsourced manuscript transcription project launched in 2010. It is run by [[University College London]]'s Bentham Project,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bentham-project |title=The Bentham Project |publisher=Ucl.ac.uk |date=2013-08-27 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> in association with other UCL partners and the [[University of London Computer Centre]]. The project makes available, via a specially-designed transcription interface, digital images of UCL's Bentham Papers collection – the unpublished writings of the philosopher [[Jeremy Bentham]], which run to some 60,000 manuscript folios – which volunteers are encouraged to transcribe. The transcripts are intended to contribute to the Bentham Project's production of the new edition of ''[[The Collected Works of Jeremy Bentham]]'', and are uploaded to UCL's digital Bentham Papers repository,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/library/bentham |title=UCL digital Bentham collection |publisher=Ucl.ac.uk |date=1996-08-20 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> widening access to the collection. Media coverage has included a feature article in ''The New York Times'',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/28/books/28transcribe.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1 |title=New York Times feature on Transcribe Bentham, 28 Dec 2010 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2010-12-28 |accessdate=2013-09-23 |first=Patricia |last=Cohen}}</ref> and a broadcast on [[Deutsche Welle]] radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/popups/popup_single_mediaplayer/0,,14808024_start_0_end_0_type_audio_struct_3126_contentId_6424149,00.html |title=Deutsche Welle World radio feature on Transcribe Bentham |publisher=Dw-world.de |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> The project was shortlisted for the 2011 Digital Heritage Award,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dish2011.nl/sessions/nominees-digital-heritage-award-2011 |title=Digital Heritage Award 2011 shortlist |publisher=Dish2011.nl |accessdate=2013-09-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026040745/http://www.dish2011.nl/sessions/nominees-digital-heritage-award-2011# |archive-date=2013-10-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and received an Award of Distinction in the Digital Communities category of the 2011 [[Prix Ars Electronica]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Austria |url=http://www.aec.at/prix/en/gewinner/2011/#digital-communities |title=Prix Ars Electronica 2011 winners |publisher=Aec.at |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> The open-source code for the project's transcription tool is available for reuse and customisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://code.google.com/p/tb-transcription-desk/ |title=Transcribe Bentham software code |publisher=Code.google.com |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> * TV by the People<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvbythepeople.com|title=tvbythepeople.com |publisher= tvbythepeople.com |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref> Is a project aimed at creating the first ever TV format through crowd wisdom. Launched in March 2013, it drew 1420 TV shows ideas submitted to tvbythepeople.com. The second phase was a six weeks development session in a closed Facebook group<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/tvbythepeople/|title=TV by the People Facebook Group |publisher= tvbythepeople.com |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref> The creative team included 580 people from four continents in a 24/7 lively debate. The project is a joint venture of Armoza Formats, Israel and [[Screentime ShinAwiL]], Ireland. [[Daniel Ravner]] initiated and led the project and crowd wisdom researcher Lior Zoref acted as consultant. The project was covered widely<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/9788906.html|title=Screentime ShinAwiL launch new 'TV By The People' venture|publisher= hotpress.com |date= 2013-04-29 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.mipworld.com/2013/09/interview-with-daniel-ravner-creating-tv-by-the-people/|title=Interview with Daniel Ravner: Creating "TV by the People"|publisher= blog.mipworld.com|date= 2013-09-02 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref> and the developed format "Turning Point" is currently in pre production.
== U == * [[Unilever]] used the crowdsourcing platform IdeaBounty<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ideabounty.com/ |title=ideabounty.com |publisher=ideabounty.com |accessdate=2013-09-23 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20100711214142/http://www.ideabounty.com/# |archive-date=2010-07-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> to find creative ideas for its next TV campaign for their snack food brand [[Peperami]].<ref name="test">[https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2009/aug/25/unilever-peperami-advertising-crowdsourcing Unilever goes crowdsourcing to spice up Peperami's TV ads], ''The Guardian''.</ref> * [[Ushahidi]] ([[Swahili language|Swahili]] for "testimony" or "witness") is a website created in the aftermath of Kenya's disputed 2007 presidential election (see [[2007–2008 Kenyan crisis]]) that collected eyewitness reports of violence sent in by email and text-message and placed them on a [[Google map]].<ref name="forbes">{{cite news |url= https://www.forbes.com/global/2008/1208/114.html |title= Citizen Voices |author= Megha Baree |date= 20 November 2008 |work= Forbes Magazine|accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref> It is also the name of the [[Open-source software|open source]] software developed for that site, which has since been improved, released freely, and used for a number of similar projects. * [[uTest]]'s business model is based on the idea that [[crowdsourcing]] is better suited to web and mobile app testing than other outsourcing models.<ref>{{cite news |title=Crowdsourcing: Now with a Real Business Model |publisher=[[Wired Magazine]] |date= December 2, 2008 |url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2008/12/crowdsourcing-n/}}</ref>
== V == * VenCorps, founded in 2008, is a venture capital fund which invests based upon crowdsourced decisions.<ref>[http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-9959387-2.html Pretend you're a venture capitalist, with VenCorps], By: Rafe Needleman, June 4, 2008, CNET</ref> * VISKON-CS, is an web based crowdsourcing infrastructure / software which is dedicated to very high resolution (VHR) satellite image analysis and disaster management/monitoring. VISKON-CS (Crowd Sourcing) presents a flexible web based software infrastructure to enable crowdsourcing for various problems, from disaster management to risk analysis or urban planning.<ref>[http://viskon.bilgem.tubitak.gov.tr TUBITAK-BILGEM], By: Fatih Kahraman, December, 2014</ref>
== W == * [[Waze]] is a free turn-by-turn GPS application for mobile phones that uses crowdsourcing to provide routing and real-time traffic updates.<ref>{{cite web|last=Terdiman |first=Daniel |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13772_3-10305132-52.html |title=CNET News – Waze iPhone app provides real-time, crowdsourced traffic data |publisher=News.cnet.com |date=2009-08-06 |accessdate=2013-09-23}}</ref> *''[[We Are The World 25 for Haiti (YouTube Edition)]]'' is a massively [[collaboration|collaborative]] [[charity record|charity]] song and music video produced by [[Canada|Canadian]] [[singer-songwriter]] [[Lisa Lavie]] and posted to the [[YouTube]] [[List of video hosting websites|video sharing website]] to raise money for victims of the January 12, [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. The video was the creation of a [[collaboration]] of 57 [[unsigned artist|unsigned]] or [[independent record label|independent]] YouTube musicians geographically distributed around the world.<ref name="CNNtranscripts201003">Textual transcripts of programs on which the CNN videos aired, are found at [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/06/smn.01.html "CNN SATURDAY MORNING NEWS"] (March 6, 2010; [https://www.webcitation.org/5rP8iAylU?url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/06/smn.01.html WebCite archive]), [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/06/cnr.02.html "CNN NEWSROOM"] (March 6, 2010; [https://www.webcitation.org/5rP8iAylb?url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/06/cnr.02.html WebCite archive]), and [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/07/sm.01.html "CNN SUNDAY MORNING"] (March 7, 2010; [https://www.webcitation.org/5rP8iAyli?url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1003/07/sm.01.html WebCite archive]).</ref> The Tokyo Times referred to J Rice's subsequently produced "We Pray for You" video, involving largely the same participants as were in Lavie's video, as an example of a trend to use [[crowdsourcing]] for [[Charity record|charitable]] purposes.<ref name="TokyoTimes20110511">Smart, Richard, [http://www.tokyotimes.jp/post/en/1829/Crowdsourcing+After+Quakebook+We+Pray+For+You.html "Crowdsourcing: After Quakebook, We Pray For You"] ([https://www.webcitation.org/5z0XgwnkQ?url=http://www.tokyotimes.jp/post/en/1829/Crowdsourcing%2BAfter%2BQuakebook%2BWe%2BPray%2BFor%2BYou.html WebCite archive]), ''The Tokyo Times'', May 11, 2011.</ref> * [[Wikipedia]] is often cited as a successful example of crowdsourcing,<ref>{{cite book |title=We are Smarter than Me |last=Libert |first=Barry|author2=Jon Spector |year=2008 |publisher=Wharton School Publishing |location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey |isbn=9780132244794 |page=3 }}</ref> despite objections by co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]] to the term.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ellen |last=Lee |title=As Wikipedia moves to S.F., founder discusses planned changes |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/11/30/BUOMTKNJA.DTL&hw=jimmy+wales&sn=001&sc=1000 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=2007-11-30 |accessdate=2008-02-19 |quote=One of my rants is against the term "crowdsourcing," which I think is a vile, vile way of looking at that world. This idea that a good business model is to get the public to do your work for free. That's just crazy. It disrespects the people. It's like you're trying to trick them into doing work for free. }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *[[Wishabi]], a Canadian online shopping platform, used to recruit a community of deal hunters to crowdsource product offers available to Canadians.<ref name="GlobeMail">The Globe and Mail:{{cite news |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/article975655.ece|title=In times of thrift, a helping hand for online shoppers|date=Mar 28, 2010 | location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail|first=Matt|last=Hartley}}</ref> Participants were rewarded with monetary incentive proportional to their individual contribution divided by the total contribution of the community. Top participants uploaded about 1,000 offers a month averaging an 80-90% accuracy rate.<ref name="WishabiDH">Wishabi:{{cite web |url= http://www.wishabi.ca/deal_|title=Deal hunting|accessdate=Mar 28, 2010}}</ref> *Word of The Hour<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wordofthehour.org |title=wordofthehour.org |publisher=wordofthehour.org |accessdate=2018-09-30}}</ref> is a web community that posts vocabulary words every hour along with translations into 10+ languages. Thousands of translations are crowdsourced<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/Word_of_The_Hour/comments/95v7rk/we_need_your_help_help_us_improve_our_translations/ |title=We need your help!! Help us improve our translations. :) |publisher=reddit.com |accessdate=2018-09-30}}</ref> by community members who subscribe on Reddit and Twitter. *[[Worth1000]] is a community focused on creative [[Competition|contests]], occasionally with financial incentives. Original contests invited members to submit manipulated images (typically using [[Photoshop]]) for specific themes, often of a comic nature. Now they have new contests regularly for photo effects (aka manipulated images), photography without effects, illustrations, writing and multimedia. While most contests are run by the website, anyone can apply to post a contest, and people seeking professional creative work like [[logo design]] are encouraged to add financial incentives to their requests for less playful creativity.
== X == * [[X-Prize]] is an innovation incentive prize using crowdsourcing mechanisms in order to tackle ''grand challenges'' that are considered failing as free markets. These represent pressing needs the humanity seeks solutions for, that previously have not been served by real entrepreneurial action. * [[Xtune|xTune]] is an enterprise social software that uses crowdsourcing to distribute work inside organizations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Intunex|url=http://www.crowdsourcing.org/site/intunex/intunexcom/19596|publisher=Crowdsourcing.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108014025/http://www.crowdsourcing.org/site/intunex/intunexcom/19596|archivedate=2012-11-08|df=}}</ref>
== Z == * [[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]] is an Internet-based [[citizen science]] project that uses the active participation of human volunteers to complete projects requiring more subtle reasoning or perception than electronic computer networks, its projects including [[Galaxy Zoo]] to amass from telescopic photographs the world's largest database of classified [[galaxy|galaxies]], and the Plankton Portal to classify [[plankton]] from about a million underwater images.<ref name=AlaskaDispatch20130924>{{cite web |url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/20130924/what-you-find-when-you-crowdsource-universe |title=What you find when you crowdsource the universe |last=Barber |first=Elizabeth |date=September 24, 2013 |website=[[Alaska Dispatch]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Kbw3aVEl?url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/20130924/what-you-find-when-you-crowdsource-universe |archivedate=October 24, 2013 }} Cites Barber's [http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2013/0924/What-do-you-find-when-you-crowdsource-the-universe ''Christian Science Monitor'' article].</ref> * [[Zooppa]] is a global social network for creative talent that crowdsources advertising. Founded in 2007, Zooppa partners with companies to launch brand sponsored advertising contests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://adage.com/goodworks/post?article_id=143138 |title=CMO Council Names 'Pause' Winners |publisher=Advertising Age |date=April 5, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |first=Karen |last=Egolf}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/05/business/media/05adnewsletter3.html |title=People and Accounts of Note in Advertising |publisher=The New York Times |date=April 2, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010}}</ref> In competition for cash prizes, members submit their original ads in response to a company's creative brief.<ref name="talentzoo.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.talentzoo.com/beyond_madison_ave/news.php/Zooppa-Rewards-Creatives-for-UserGenerated-Advertising/?articleID=7372 |title=Zooppa Rewards Creatives for User-Generated Advertising |publisher=TalentZoo.com |date=May 4, 2010 |accessdate=May 4, 2010 |first=Megan |last=Green}}</ref> Grand prize winners are selected by the brands, and additional awards are given to creators as determined by vote of the Zooppa community and selection by the Zooppa staff.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://videocontestking.wordpress.com/2010/04/03/zooppa-a-good-model/ |title=Zooppa – A Good Model |publisher=Video Contest King |date=April 3, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |first=Jared |last=Cicon |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409062839/http://videocontestking.wordpress.com/2010/04/03/zooppa-a-good-model/# |archive-date=2010-04-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=125429 |title='Pause for Cause' Picks Creative Contest Winners |publisher=MediaPost |date=April 5, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407091119/http://www.mediapost.com/publications/?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=125429# |archive-date=2010-04-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> As of May 2010, more than 70 brands have launched crowdsourced advertising campaigns on Zooppa's platform including [[Google]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[The Hershey Company|Hershey's]], [[General Mills]], [[Microsoft]], [[NBC Universal]], and [[Mini Cooper]].<ref name="talentzoo.com"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/prnewswire/LA96458.htm |title=Universal Studios Hollywood Challenges Filmmakers... |publisher=CNNMoney.com |date=April 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>

'''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|Majlis}}''' (or '''Mejlis'''; {{lang-ar|مجلس}}, pl. {{lang|ar|مجالس}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|Majālis}}'') is an [[Arabic language|Arabic]] term meaning "a place of sitting", used in the context of "council", to describe various types of special gatherings among common interest groups be it administrative, social or religious in countries with linguistic or cultural connections to [[Islamic world|Islamic countries]]. It shares its [[Semitic root|root]] with the verb meaning 'to sit,' {{lang|ar|جلس}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|jalasa}}'' (cf. [[British English]] '[[sitting room]]'). The ''Majlis'' can refer to a [[legislature]] as well and is used in the name of legislative councils or assemblies in some of the states where [[Islamic]] culture dominates.<ref>{{cite web|title=عن المجلس|url=http://www.almajles.gov.ae/Pages/Home.aspx|work=[[Federal National Council]]|year=2011|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.majlis.ir/ Parliament of the Islamic Republic of Iran].</ref> The term ''Majlis'' is used to refer to a private place where guests are received and entertained.<ref name="auto">[http://www.dubaicityguide.com/site/news/news-details.asp?newsid=26658&newstype=Latest%2024%20Hrs%20News The Majlis Of The Future Today] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722021734/http://www.dubaicityguide.com/site/news/news-details.asp?newsid=26658&newstype=Latest%2024%20Hrs%20News |date=2011-07-22 }} — Leading UAE Interior Designers Set To Reveal Their Visions At Index, [http://www.dubaicityguide.com/ Dubai City Guide], 9 November 2009.</ref> Among the [[Shia]] community the term ''Majlis'' is used as a verb meaning to the gathering who came to remember [[Ahl al-Bayt]] and in particular [[Husayn ibn Ali|Hussain ibn-e-Ali]].
== Legislatures == * [[Azerbaijan]] — the [[National Assembly of Azerbaijan|National Assembly]] is known as ''Milli Məclis'' * [[Circassians Majlis]] — The Unity between the coastal [[Adyghe people|Adyghe]] Tribes in [[Circassia]] * [[Crimea]] ([[Ukraine]]-aligned) — [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]] * [[Cyprus]] — ''Temsilciler Meclisi'', Republic of Cyprus' [[House of Representatives (Cyprus)|House of Representatives]] ** [[Northern Cyprus]] — ''Cumhuriyet Meclisi'', Northern Cyprus' [[Assembly of the Republic (Northern Cyprus)|Assembly of the Republic]] * [[Indonesia]] — The [[People's Consultative Assembly]] of Indonesia s ''Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat'' (MPR) * [[Iran]] — The [[Islamic Consultative Assembly]] is known as ''Majles-e Showrā-ye Eslāmī'' * [[Kazakhstan]] — [[Majilis]] * [[Kuwait]] — The [[National Assembly of Kuwait]] is known in Arabic as ''Majlis-al-Umma'' * [[Maldives]] — [[Majlis of the Maldives]] * [[Oman]] — [[Consultative Assembly of Oman|Majlis of Oman]] * [[Pakistan]] — The [[Parliament of Pakistan]] is officially known as the ''Majlis-e-Shoora'' * [[Saudi Arabia]] — [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia|Majlis of Saudi Arabia]] * [[Tajikistan]] - the bicameral [[Supreme Assembly (Tajikistan)|Supreme Assembly]] is known as the ''Majlisi Oli'', the upper house [[National Assembly]] being known as the ''Majlis-i Milli'', while the Assembly of Representatives, the lower house, is known as the ''Majlis-is Namoyandagon'' * [[Turkey]] — the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|Grand National Assembly]] is known as ''Türkiye Büyük Millet Meclisi'' * [[Turkmenistan]] — the [[Assembly of Turkmenistan]] is known as the ''Türkmenistanyň mejlisi'' * [[Uzbekistan]] — The [[Supreme Assembly of Uzbekistan|Oliy Majlis]]
==Residential== [[File:The Grand Majlis.jpg|thumb|Majlis]] The term ''Majlis'' is also used to refer to a private place where guests, usually male, are received and entertained.<ref name="auto"/> Frequently, the room has cushions placed around the walls where the visitors sit, either with the cushions placed directly on the floor or upon a raised shelf.
In many [[Arab]] homes, the majlis is the meeting room or front [[parlor]] used to entertain visitors. In [[Saudi Arabia]], the decoration of the majlis in the home is often the responsibility of the women of the house, who either decorate the area themselves or [[barter]] with other women to do it for them. In the [[Asir]] Province and in neighboring parts of [[Yemen]], geometric designs and bright colors are used in "majlis painting" or [[nagash painting]]. The term ''majlis'' is used to refer to a private place where house guests and friends are received and entertained. Because hospitality is taken seriously, many families take pride in making their guests comfortable when visiting.<ref name="auto"/>
Sometimes public waiting rooms are also called a majlis, since this is an area where people meet and visit. Here the traditional "majlis painting or [[nagash painting]] has been added to the [[interior design]] of the room. The provincial airport in [[Abha]] has recently been designed to reflect the cultural heritage of the region, an airport official said: “Abha is the first city in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to have its airport decorated in a local-heritage style,” said Provincial Airport Director [[Abdul Aziz Abu Harba]]. “The seating arrangement at the airport lounge has been in the form of a traditional majlis and the walls are painted in various colors reflecting the natural beauty of Asir.”<ref>[http://www.arabnews.com/node/378076 MISHAAL AL-TAMIMI. 2011 “Abha airport reflects heritage.”] ARAB NEWS Thursday 19 May 2011.</ref>
In the [[Najd]] province of Saudi Arabia, wall coverings include stars shapes and other geometric designs carved into the wall covering itself. "[[Courtyard]]s and upper pillared [[portico]]es are principal features of the best Nadjdi architecture, in addition to the fine incised plaster wood ([[jiss]]) and painted window shutters, which decorate the reception rooms. Good examples of plasterwork can often be seen in the gaping ruins of torn-down buildings- the effect is light, delicate and airy. It is usually around the majlis, around the coffee hearth and along the walls above where guests sat on rugs, against cushions. Doughty wondered if this "[[parquet]]ting of jis", this "[[gypsum]] fretwork... all adorning and unenclosed" originated from [[India]]. However, the Najd fretwork seems very different from that seen in the Eastern Province and [[Oman]], which are linked to Indian traditions, and rather resembles the motifs and patterns found in ancient [[Mesopotamia]]. The rosette, the star, the triangle and the stepped pinnacle pattern of dadoes are all ancient patterns, and can be found all over the [[Middle East]] of antiquity. [[Al-Qassim Region|Qassim]] seems to be the home of this art, and there it is normally worked in hard white [[plaster]] (though what you see is usually begrimed by the smoke of the coffee hearth). In [[Riyadh]], examples can be seen in unadorned [[clay]]."<ref>Mostyn, Trevor. 1983. Saudi Arabia. London: Middle East Economic Digest. Pages 257-258.</ref>
== Other uses == * '''Majlis''' is also the name of an organisation in Mumbai which works for women's rights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.majlislaw.com/|title=Majlis Legal Centre is a forum for women's rights discourse and legal initiatives|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * '''Majlis''' is also used to mean a ''[[Salon (gathering)|salon]]'' (musical or scientific), especially during the [[Abbasid]] era, e.g., for discussing the recent translations from Greek.<ref>[[Melvyn Bragg]], ''"[[In Our Time (BBC Radio 4)|In Our Time]]"'' broadcast, [[BBC Radio 4]], 2 October 2008.</ref> This sense is sometimes now distinguished as an "adabi majlis" ("artistic majlis"). See [[Dewaniya]] * ''The Majlis'' is the title of a Muslim periodical published in South Africa.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.themajlis.co.za/|title=Mujlisul Ulama of South Africa|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * '''MAJLIS''' is used as the name of the annual conference held by the Middle East Oracle User Group ([http://www.meoug.com/ MEOUG])

'''Masculine psychology''' refers to an archetypal gender-related [[psychology]] supposedly of [[male]] [[human]] [[Identity (social science)|identity]]. It is examined through the lenses of history, which have produced standard culture, especially as it relates to [[gender studies]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smedley|first=Audrey|date=1998|title="Race" and the Construction of Human Identity|jstor=682047|journal=American Anthropologist|volume=100|issue=3|pages=690–702}}</ref> [[Sex differences in humans|Gender differences]] are determined from a scientific and [[empirical]] approach, while the other approaches are theorized as they are aligned to the [[psychoanalysis|psychoanalytic tradition]]. Psychoanalytic approaches have cultivated concepts like [[masculinity]] and [[machismo]] because of biased analytic inclusions.
== Western Masculine Psychology == Enlightenment of modern history became an influencing discipline during the [[Renaissance]]. Intellectual approaches of modern philosophy shaped cultural customs as thinkers became fixated with creating a world through law, artistic representation, western expansion, social structure, and ultimately [[Power (social and political)|control]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2017/entries/colonialism/|title=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|last=Kohn|first=Margaret|last2=Reddy|first2=Kavita|date=2017|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2017}}</ref>
{{See also|Manifest destiny|l1=Manifest Destiny}}
The masculine psychology is the effect of [[Gender differences|gender differencing]], which was closely governed resulting Europe's western political and social control. Conflict of social structures became evident in society as there were beliefs in liberty through common resistance, such as [[Rebellions of 1837–1838|protest writing]]. Writers, artists, and liberalist alike rebelled from social structures through their forms of artistry.
== History ==
=== Influence from a Western Religion === {{Main|God and gender (disambiguation){{!}}God and gender}} The original languages of several religions have gender-specific pronouns and verb conjugations. As language was constructed by man, references to [[God]] often use the masculine pronoun "He" and refer to [[God]] as masculine; social modernity enabled hegemonic language.
In many religions, including [[Judaism]], [[Sikhism]], and Islam, God has traditionally been referred to by using masculine pronouns. However, in the original Hebrew and Aramaic languages of the Old Testament, God is referred to by a variety of names, in both singular and plural forms, and so it is not clear that the use of a masculine pronoun necessarily conveys actual gender. For example, in Sikhism the use of masculine pronouns is due to grammatical conventions and does not signify actual gender. In [[Islam]], similarly, God is generally depicted as having a male gender, though there may be debate as to God's gender. As there is no neutral gender in Arabic, God is referred to in the masculine form by default, and it is universally understood that God (Allah) is not a woman.
In [[Mainstream Christianity]] God is understood as a [[Trinity]] of three persons in one God, consisting of Father, Son, and [[Holy Spirit]]. While in mainstream Christianity God is thought of in masculine terms, teachings generally state that God has no gender, except in his incarnation as Jesus Christ, due to the fact that He is a spiritual being. However, the names of Father and Son clearly imply masculinity, and the Gospel of John implies the masculinity of the Spirit by applying a masculine demonstrative pronoun to the grammatically neuter [[Antecedent (grammar)|antecedent]]. Still, teachings regarding the gender and nature of God vary between Christian groups, and some clearly state that God is male. These include the teachings of [[the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]], which explicitly describe God the Father as being male, corporeal, and separate in being from the Son, Jesus Christ. Unusually, Latter-day Saint teachings also indicate the existence of a Heavenly Mother, who is the wife of the Heavenly Father, and that together they are the spiritual parents of humankind. This reinforces the idea that God is analogous to our earthly fathers. However, these beliefs are not common among Christian groups, which generally see God as having both male and female attributes and therefore no need for a female counterpart.
In many polytheistic religions, there are both gods and goddesses clearly defined. This includes many pagan religions, such as those involving [[Greek mythology]], [[Norse mythology]], and [[Celtic mythology]]. This distinction also exists in other polytheisms. For example, [[Hinduism]] distinguishes between God and Goddess. There are three main male gods known as Tridev (Sanskrit:त्रिदेव) and their wives are worshiped as goddesses. In Hindu mythology, all the forces converge to form a female supreme power known as aadishakti (Sanskrit: आदिशक्ति.).
The western masculine psychology derived from religious social structures that created ideologies of masculinity (and femininity).
{{See also|Masculinity}}
== Ideologies of Manhood == Among artists and scientists during the [[Renaissance]], it was the prevailing belief that the study of the male form was in itself a study of God. [[Michelangelo's David|Michelangelo's ''David'']] is based upon this artistic discipline, which is known as ''[[disegno]]''. Under this discipline, sculpture is considered to be the finest form of art because it mimics [[divinity|divine]] creation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/cultureshock/flashpoints/visualarts/david_a.html|title=Culture Shock: Flashpoints: Visual Arts: Michelangelo's David|website=www.pbs.org|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> Because [[Michelangelo]] adhered to the concepts of ''disegno'', he worked under the premise that the image of ''David'' was already in the block of stone he was working on—in much the same way as the human [[soul]] is thought by some to be found within the physical body as concluded by [[psychoanalytic theory]].
Masculine identities or concepts are developed differently across cultures and subcultures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abc-clio.com/ABC-CLIOCorporate/product.aspx?pc=A3201C|title=Masculine Identities|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-08}}</ref> Because masculinity can take varied forms, forms of manliness can be changed and utilized at once. Masculine identities are not limited to the archetypal male species, and can be [[Gender fluid|fluid]] in constructing a new identity outside of [[Gender binary|binary]] lenses.
{{See also|Genderqueer}}
== Law == The quest for control and understanding became the Britain's [[Victorian era|Victorian period]], and the creation of laws to fit societal structure was later the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment period]]. [[Law]]s stood in place to dictate order.
[[Sodomy law|Sodomy]] was a 1789 law that enforced masculinity in western culture, and specifically, sexual acts by men was deemed illegal. As this law was never repealed since, sodomy laws began to be used in a new way during the late 1960's - distinctly against people who identify as [[gay]]. As the [[LGBT social movements|gay rights movement]] began to make headway, and the social condemnation of being gay began to weaken, social conservatives invoked sodomy laws as a justification for discrimination.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aclu.org/other/why-sodomy-laws-matter|title=Why Sodomy Laws Matter|work=American Civil Liberties Union|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en}}</ref> The gradual [[liberalization]] of the Western sexuality, especially in Northern America, led government officials sodomy laws in most states. Several northern American states out-ruled sodomy in just 2003 and culture remains a continuity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.alternet.org/story/99092/the_strange_history_of_sodomy_laws|title=The Strange History of Sodomy Laws|last=Canaday|first=Margot|date=2008-09-16|work=AlterNet|access-date=2018-04-08}}</ref>
Throughout the quest of control, literature was used to rebel against standard ideologies, for ambiguous forms of same-sex love had so significant during the Victorian culture; "homoaffectional" literature became, both, more explicit in its sexuality and much less common as time progressed. The lack of acknowledging sexual preferences outside of the binary social constructs are effects of an unchallenged masculine psychology.
==Literature== Social standards of manliness or masculinity has been challenged as much as it is asserted in the Western culture. The study of masculine psychology has brought about the publication of many books, poems, and journals.
* '''Robert Bly'''
[[Robert Bly]] inspired the [[mythopoetic men's movement]] with his 1990 book ''[[Iron John: A Book About Men]]''<ref>{{Cite book|title=Iron John: A Book About Men|last=Bly|first=Robert|publisher=|year=1990|isbn=0-201-51720-5|location=|pages=}}</ref> consisting of retellings of archetypal male myths and analysis of the [[Grimms' Fairy Tales|Grimms' Fairy Tale]] "Iron John".
* '''David Deida'''
[[David Deida]], a noted author and spiritual practitioner, published ''The Way Of The Superior Man: A Spiritual Guide to Mastering the Challenges of Woman, Work, and Sexual Desire'' in 1997. In this book he argues "It is time to evolve beyond the (first-stage) macho jerk ideal, all spine and no heart. It is also time to evolve beyond the (second-stage) sensitive and caring wimp ideal, all heart and no spine. Heart and spine must be united in a single man, and then gone beyond in the fullest expression of love and consciousness possible, which requires a deep relaxation into the infinite openness of this present moment. And this takes a new kind of (third-stage) guts. This is the way of the superior man."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Way of the Superior Man: A Spiritual Guide to Mastering the challenges of Women, Work, and Sexual Desire|last=Deida|first=David|publisher=|year=2004|isbn=9781591792574|location=|pages=}}</ref> Literary critiques of David Deida include the fact that he encourages men to express their sexuality in a manner that still reflects the same attitudes.
* '''Susan Faludi'''
[[Susan Faludi]], a noted feminist author, published ''[[Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man]]'' in 1999. In this book she claims that in the 20th century men suffered from the breakdown of patriarchal structures.
* '''Robert Moore and Douglas Gillette'''
[[Robert L. Moore]] and Douglas Gillette collaborated on a series of five books on male psychology and [[Mythopoetic men's movement|mythopoetic]] aspects of human development, including ''King, Warrior, Magician, Lover'', and a book exploring each of these four [[archetypes]]. The book and its authors are considered important parts of the [[men's movement]] in the latter part of the 20th century.
* '''Anne McClintock'''
''The White Family of Man: Colonial Discourse and the Reinvention of Patriarchy'' (1994). "This text chronicles the dangerous liaisons between gender, race and class that shaped British [[British imperialism|imperialism]] and its bloody dismantling. Spanning the century between Victorian Britain and the recent struggle for power in South Africa, the book takes up the complex relationships between race, sexuality, and more.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/3006942|title=Imperial leather : race, gender, and sexuality in the colonial conquest in SearchWorks catalog|website=searchworks.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-08}}</ref>
* '''Eugene Monick'''
In his books ''Phallos: Sacred Image of the Masculine'' and ''Castration and Male Rage'', Monick correlates male sexuality and spirituality, arguing that the "[[phallos]]" (erect penis) is something of an existential God-image for men. He also presents his thesis that there is a difference between [[masculinity]] and [[patriarchy]]. The author also argues that there is a deep need within men to participate in a [[Bachelor band|fraternity]] with men and to have their maleness recognized by other men, but that our society often does not take this into account. The author claims that what usually results is that these needs become frustrated and manifest themselves in often anti-social behavior and activities, such as [[hazing]] rituals.
* '''Dee Rees'''
Female Masculinity in [[Dee Rees]]'s ''Pariah'' is viewed through many different facets as it explores identity and sexuality. This film offers multiple definitions of the monolithic black feminist that is often thought of in a singular aspect. ''Pariah'' goes against the concept of a binary heterosexist expression of sexuality, for it challenges the concepts of “masculinity” and “aggressiveness” in women. All women who choose this form of sexuality are not limited to one definition of the “third gender”. This film represents the attitudes of the black community towards the “third gender” by revealing that African Americans can offer complex identity formation, which validates humanism in a patriarchal society.
* '''William Shakespeare'''
Shakespeare's works are politically influenced as the following plays comment on western [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] constructs such as family, monarch, nature, religion, law, and the Renaissance, respectively: ''Titus Andronicus'' (Family), ''Richard III'' (Monarchy), ''A Midsummer’s Night’s Dream'' (Nature), ''Hamlet'' (Religion), ''Measure for Measure'' (Law), ''Antony and Cleopatra'' (Renaissance).
* '''Percy B. Shelley'''
'''Percy''' Bysshe '''Shelley''', whose literary career was marked with controversy due conflicting social agendas, is a figures of English romanticism (following the Renaissance).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/percy-bysshe-shelley|title=Percy Bysshe Shelley|last=Shelley|first=Percy Bysshe|date=1999-04-03|website=Percy Bysshe Shelley|language=en|access-date=2018-04-08}}</ref> ''The Keepsake'' (1828) reveals his ideas about religion, socialism, and free love, especially in his essay "On Love".
* '''Justin Torres'''
''We the Animals'' (2014) highlights character psychology, familial structure, the learned behavior of masculinity, and it encourages one to imagine a utopian space in which civil and human rights are not tied to a compliance with heteronormative lifestyles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jetfuelreview.com/justin-torress-we-the-animals.html|title=Justin Torres's We the Animals|website=Jet Fuel Review|language=en|access-date=2018-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rohrleitner|first=Marion Christina|date=2017-01-24|title=Refusing the Referendum: Queer Latino Masculinities and Utopian Citizenship in Justin Torres’ We the Animals|url=http://journals.openedition.org/ejas/11856|journal=European journal of American studies|language=fr|volume=11|issue=3|doi=10.4000/ejas.11856|issn=1991-9336}}</ref>
==The male fear of the feminine== The male fear of the feminine is a phenomenon that has been discussed since the 1930s. It was first introduced by the German psychoanalyst and critic of Freudian theory, [[Karen Horney]] (1932) in her paper titled "The Dread of Woman."<ref>{{cite journal | last = Horney | first = Karen | title = Observations on a specific difference in the dread felt by men and by women respectively for the opposite sex | journal = [[The International Journal of Psychoanalysis]] | volume = 13 | pages = 348–360 | publisher = [[British Psychoanalytical Society|Institute of Psychoanalysis]] | date = 1932 | url = http://www.pep-web.org/document.php?id=ijp.013.0348a | ref = harv | postscript = .}} :''Reproduced in'': Horney, Karen (1999), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nYWfBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT241 The dread of woman: Observations on a specific difference in the dread felt by men and by women respectively for the opposite sex]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Grigg | editor-first1 = Russell | editor-last2 = Hecq | editor-first2 = Dominique | editor-last3 = Smith | editor-first3 = Craig R. | title = Female sexuality: the early psychoanalytic controversies | pages = 241–252 | publisher = Karnac | location = London, England | isbn = 9781782200222 }}</ref> [[Erich Neumann (psychologist)|Erich Neumann]] (1954), a German-born [[Jung]]ian analyst, dedicated one essay to the discussion, titled "The fear of the feminine" (Orig: ''Die Angst vor dem Weiblichen'', 1959). Neumann regards "patriarchal normality as a form of fear of the feminine" (p. 261).<ref>{{cite book | last = Neumann | first = Erich | title = The fear of the feminine and other essays on feminine psychology | publisher = Princeton University Press | location = Princeton, N.J | year = 1994 | isbn = 9780691034744 }} :(First published in German as: die Angst vor dem Weiblichen, 1959. Zürich: Racher Verlag)</ref>
A later contributor is Chris Blazina, a psychodynamic psychologist and professor based at Tennessee State University. Blazina considers that "the fear of the feminine helps define what is masculine" (1997).<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Blazina | first = Chris | title = The fear of the feminine in the Western psyche and the masculine task of disidentification: their effect on the development of masculine gender role conflict | journal = [[The Journal of Men's Studies]] | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–68 | publisher = [[Sage Publishing|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/106082659700600103 | date = October 1997 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/106082659700600103 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/106082659700600103 Pdf.] * ''See also'': {{cite book | last = Blazina | first = Chris | title = The cultural myth of masculinity | publisher = Praeger | location = Westport, Connecticut | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780275979904 }}</ref> In 1986, James O'Neil et al. theorized that the male fear of the feminine is a core aspect of the male psyche. He developed a 37-question psychometric test, a gender role conflict scale (GRCS), to measure the extent to which a man is in conflict with traditional masculine role values. This test is built upon the notion of the male fear of the feminine.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = O'Neil | first1 = James M. | last2 = Helms | first2 = Barbara J. | last3 = Gable | first3 = Robert K. | last4 = David | first4 = Laurence | last5 = Wrightsman | first5 = Lawrence S. | title = Gender-role conflict scale: College men's fear of femininity | journal = [[Sex Roles (journal)|Sex Roles]] | volume = 14 | issue = 5–6 | pages = 335–350 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1007/BF00287583 | date = March 1986 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00287583 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
In 2003, Werner Kierski, a London-based German-born psychotherapist and researcher, associated with [[humanistic psychology]] and [[transpersonal]] and [[existential psychotherapy]] designed the first empirical research into the male fear of the feminine<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kierski | first = Werner | title = Female violence: can we therapists face up to it? | journal = Counselling and Psychotherapy Journal | volume = 13 | issue = 10 | pages = 32–35 | publisher = [[British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy]] (BACP) | date = December 2002 | url = http://www.dewar4research.org/DOCS/kierski.pdf | issn = 1474-5372 | ref = harv | postscript = . | deadurl = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161209212508/http://www.dewar4research.org/DOCS/kierski.pdf | archivedate = 2016-12-09 | df = }}</ref> with the results published in 2007 and presented to the public at the 2007 annual conference of the American Men's Studies Association (AMSA) and at the 2007 research conference of the [[British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy]] (BACP).<ref name="Kierski_2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Kierski | first1 = Werner | title = Men and the fear of the feminine | journal = Self & Society | volume = 34 | issue = 5 | pages = 27–33 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/03060497.2007.11083943 | date = March–April 2007 | url = https://doi.org/10.1080/03060497.2007.11083943 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
According to the various sources, the male fear of the feminine is connected to influences from their mothers and to cultural norms that prescribe how men must behave in order to feel accepted as men.
When men experience vulnerable feelings and other feelings that are associated with women, men can become frightened. According to Kierski (2007), the fear of the feminine then acts in two ways: a) Like an internal monitor to ensure that men stay within the boundaries of what is regarded as masculine, i.e. being action orientated, self-reliant, guarded, and seemingly independent; b) if a man fails to experience this and feels out of control, vulnerable or dependent, the fear of the feminine can act like a defense, leading to splitting off, [[Psychological repression|repressing]], or projecting those feelings.<ref name="Kierski_2007" />
'''Figure 1: Male fear of the feminine as an internal monitor and as a defense. Source: Werner Kierski.'''
<gallery> Image:FOF_monitor.jpg|Male fear of the feminine as an internal monitor. Image:FOF_defence.jpg|Male fear of the feminine as a psychological defense. </gallery>
Kierski's research claimed that men do acknowledge that male fear of the feminine can have a strong influence on both hetero- and homosexual men. The research has also indicated that there appears to be a link between fear of the feminine and men's negative views about counseling and [[psychotherapy]]. In addition, this research has identified four possible groups of experiences that lead to male fear of the feminine, which relate to internal and external triggers. These are: Experiencing vulnerability and uncertainty; women who are strong and competent; women who are angry or aggressive; women who are like their mothers.<ref name="Kierski_2007" />
==Homophobia== Constructions of race and sexuality in the western world caused particular expressions of homophobic racism and sexual violence. Defying traditional gender expectations became unacceptable and spectacles are labeled as “other” for disregarding [gender] norms.
Issues of [[homophobia]] and [[gay bashing]] are of relevance to the study of masculine psychology. Every year, men (such as [[Matthew Shepard]]) die as a result of [[gay bashing]]. The victims of gay bashing attacks are most often [[homosexual]] males, or those who display what are commonly perceived as effeminate behaviors or [[mannerism]]s which are, when seen in males, often associated with homosexuality. Self-identified [[heterosexual]] males are usually the perpetrators of gay bashing attacks.
Sigmund Freud presented the thesis that everyone is at some level [[bisexual]], and [[Alfred Kinsey]] research results claimed that as many as 37% of American males had engaged in homosexual activity. French-Canadian psychologist Guy Corneau says that despite Kinsey's research results, attitudes toward homosexuality have remained hostile.
The author says it is puzzling that we live in what he considers a male-dominated society, and yet very little work has been done to understand the [[archetypal]] basis of masculinity. He suggests that this may be due to a societal assumption of male superiority, founded on the belief that one should not question that which is deemed to be right and superior.
See also: [[Gay panic defense]] and [[Violence#Psychology and sociology|Violence § Psychology and sociology]]
