[[File:February 23rd 1908 Boys Selling Newspapers on Brooklyn Bridge.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|[[Brooklyn]] newsboys, 1908]] {{Youth rights sidebar}}
The '''newsboys' strike of 1899''' was a U.S. [[youth activism|youth-led campaign]] to force change in the way that [[Joseph Pulitzer]] and [[William Randolph Hearst]]'s newspapers compensated their [[child labor]] force of [[newspaper hawker]]s. The strikers demonstrated across the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] for several days, effectively bringing traffic to a standstill,<ref>Haw, R. (2005) ''The Brooklyn Bridge: A Cultural History.'' Rutgers University Press. p. 151.</ref> along with the news distribution for many [[New England]] cities. The [[Strike action|strike]] lasted two weeks, causing Pulitzer's ''[[New York World]]'' to decrease its circulation from 360,000 papers sold per day to 125,000.<ref>Nasaw, David. (1999) "Ch. 3: Youse an' yer noble scrap: On strike with the Newsboy Legion in 1899." in ''Big Town, Big Time.'' New York: New York Daily News. p. 9.</ref> Although the price of papers was not lowered, the strike was successful in forcing the World and Journal to offer full buy-backs to their sellers, thus increasing the amount of money that newsies received for their work.<ref>Mott, F.L. (2000) ''American Journalism''. New York: Routledge. p. 598.</ref>
==Background==
At the turn of the century, newsboys were essential to newspaper distribution. While morning editions of the paper were often delivered directly to subscribers, the afternoon editions relied almost exclusively on newsboys to sell.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Children of the City: At Work and at Play|last=Nasaw|first=David|publisher=Anchor Press|year=1985|isbn=|location=Garden City, New York|pages=}}</ref> Most of the newsboys came from poor immigrant families and sold papers in the afternoons and evenings, after their school finished. They bought papers at 50¢ per hundred, and sold them at 1¢ each for a profit of half a cent per paper.<ref name=":0" />
There were newsboy strikes several years before the events of 1899, including those in [[Newsboys' strike of 1884|1884]],<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07E7D6163AEF33A25757C1A9669D94659FD7CF&scp=11&sq=Newsboys+Strike&st=p "Newsboys strike"], ''New York Times.'' October 14, 1884. Retrieved 14 February 2008.</ref> [[Newsboys' strike of 1867|1886]],<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9800E1D91330E533A25753C3A9659C94679FD7CF&scp=3&sq=Newsboys+Strike&st=p "Newsboys indulge in a strike"], ''New York Times.'' March 30, 1886. Retrieved 14 February 2008.</ref> [[Newsboys' strike of 1887|1887]],<ref>[http://query.nytimes./gst/abstract.html?res=9907E4DD153FE432A2575AC2A9679C94669FD7CF&scp=5&sq=Newsboys+Strike&st=p "Strike of newsboys"]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''New York Times.'' January 9, 1897. Retrieved 4 February 2000.</ref> and [[Newsboys' strike of 1881|1881]].<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=980DE0D91030E633A25750C1A96E9C94689FD7CF&scp=1&sq=Newsboys+Strike&st=p "Newsboys on strike: Many fights and two arrested by police"], ''New York Times.'' August 13, 1889. Retrieved 14 February 2008.</ref> The last notable strike that the newsboys held against the ''World'' and the ''Journal'' was in [[Newsboys' strike of May 1894|May 1894]].<ref>[http://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-herald/july-21-1899/ "Newsboys Strike for Better Terms"], ''New York Herald.'' July 21, 1899</ref>
==Causes== In 1898, with the [[Spanish–American War]] increasing newspaper sales, several publishers raised the cost of a newsboy bundle of 100 newspapers from 50¢ to 60¢,<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1889/08/13/100966784.pdf "Newsboys on Strike"], ''New York''. August 13, 1889</ref> a price increase that at the time was offset by the increased sales. After the war, many papers reduced the cost back to previous levels, with the notable exceptions of ''[[The Evening World]]'' and the ''[[New York Evening Journal]]''.<ref>[http://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-times/july-21-1899/ "Newsboys Go On Strike"], ''New York Times''. July 21, 1899</ref>
==Strike== [[File:Child Labor in United States 1910 working night shift.jpg|thumb|left|Newsies often worked late, past midnight. Above, a newsboy working in New York (1910).]]
=== Early Days === On July 18, 1899, a group of newsboys in [[Long Island City]] turned over a distribution wagon for the ''New York Journal'' and declared a strike against the papers of [[Joseph Pulitzer]], publisher of the ''World'', and [[William Randolph Hearst]], publisher of the ''Journal'' until prices were rolled back to 50¢ per hundred.<ref name=":0" /> The newsboys of [[Manhattan]] and [[Brooklyn]] were quick to follow the next day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/brooklyn-eagle/july-20-1899/|title=July 20, 1899: “Newsboys Start A Strike.”|date=2016-01-01|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
The newsboys' methods were violent in the early days of the strike. Any man or boy found to be selling the two boycotted papers would be mobbed by a group of strikers, beaten, and his papers destroyed.<ref>[http://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-24-1899a/ "Plan to Down Newsboys"], ''The Sun''. 24 July 1899</ref> The newspaper owners paid grown men to sell their papers, offering them police protection, but the strikers often found ways to distract the officers so they could get at the "scabs."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-23-1899/|title=July 23, 1899: “Newsboys’ Strike Swells”|date=2013-02-14|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Women and girls fared a little better because, as union leader Kid Blink put it, "A feller can't soak a lady."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-23-1899/|title=July 23, 1899: “Newsboys’ Strike Swells”|date=2013-02-14|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
The newsboys also distributed flyers and hung signs around the city encouraging people to help them in their cause by not buying the ''World'' and ''Journal''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-22-1899/|title=July 22, 1899: “Boy Strikers Sweep the City”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Rally at Irving Hall === On July 24, 1899, the newsboys held a city-wide rally at [[Irving Place Theatre|Irving Hall]] sponsored by state senator [[Timothy Sullivan|Timothy D. Sullivan]]. An estimated five thousand boys from Manhattan attended the rally, along with two thousand boys from Brooklyn and several hundred from other areas of the city.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-herald/july-25-1899/|title=July 25, 1899: “Newsboys Wage A Merry War”|date=2013-08-30|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
Many local business men and politicians addressed the crowd, including lawyer Leonard A. Suitkin, Frank B. Wood, and ex-Assemblyman Phil Wissig. When the adults had finished speaking, union president David Simmons read a list of resolutions saying that the strike was to stand until the papers reduced their prices, and also calling on the newsboys to adopt non-violent methods of resistance.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-25-1899a/|title=July 25, 1899: “Great Meet of Newsboys”|date=2013-02-20|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
Other speeches were made by "Warhorse" Brennan, Jack Tietjen, "Bob the Indian", [https://newsboys-of-1899.tumblr.com/post/167557956970/kid-blinks-speech-at-the-rally union leader "Kid Blink,"] "Crazy" Arborn, Annie Kelly, and [https://newsboys-of-1899.tumblr.com/post/167593280083/race-track-higgins-speech-at-the-rally Brooklyn leader "Racetrack" Higgins]. The night ended with a song sung by "Hungry Joe" Kernan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-25-1899a/|title=July 25, 1899: “Great Meet of Newsboys”|date=2013-02-20|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
A floral horseshoe was offered to Kid Blink as a reward for giving the best speech of the evening.
=== After the Rally === In the days following the rally, the newsboys' tactics changed to be non-violent. Even though they were no longer beating people who sold the ''World'' and ''Journal'', the strike was still effective since by then the public was on their side and chose not to buy them even if they were for sale.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-25-1899/|title=July 25, 1899: “Newsboy Strike Gains Ground”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
On July 26, 1899 the newsboys planned a parade where as many as 6,000 boys would march accompanied by a band and fireworks, but this parade never happened due to issues with obtaining a permit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-26-1899/|title=July 26, 1899: “Newsboys Ready to Show Strength”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Kid Blink Disgraced === On July 26, 1899, rumors spread among the newsboys that strike leaders Kid Blink and David Simmons had betrayed the strike and agreed to sell the boycotted papers in exchange for a bribe from the newspaper executives.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-times/july-27-1899/|title=July 27,1899: “Newsboys Are Weakening”|date=2013-02-11|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Both boys denied the charges, but some sources note that Kid Blink wore clothes a bit nicer than usual.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-28-1899/|title=July 28, 1899: “Newsboys See Victory Ahead”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> In response to these suspicions, Kid Blink and David Simmons resigned from their leadership positions, Simmons changing from union president to treasurer, and Kid Blink becoming a walking delegate.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/july-30-1899-supplement/|title=July 30, 1899: “New-York Newsboys,” Illustrated Supplement|date=2013-02-12|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
That night, Kid Blink was chased through the streets by a group of boys angry about the rumors that he had abandoned the strike. A police officer, seeing the group of running boys, grabbed Kid Blink, assuming he was leading them, and arrested him for disorderly conduct. Kid Blink was given a fine and let go while a group of newsboys outside the court jeered at him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-28-1899/|title=July 28, 1899: “Newsboys See Victory Ahead”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== The End of the Strike === After the rumors of Kid Blink and David Simmons' desertion of the strike, combined with their failure to obtain a parade permit, the newsboys' faith in centralized leadership was diminished.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-28-1899/|title=July 28, 1899: “Newsboys See Victory Ahead”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Other newsboys stepped up to lead the strikers,<ref name=":2" /> but none of them had the same level of power and influence as Kid Blink once had.
On August 1, 1899, the ''World'' and ''Journal'' offered the newsboys a compromise: the price of a hundred papers would remain at 60¢, but they would buy back any unsold papers. This meant that boys who had trouble selling all their papers would not be forced to sell late into the night to avoid taking a loss for the day. The newsboys accepted this compromise, ending the strike and disbanding the union on August 2, 1899.<ref>[http://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/aug-2-1899/ "Newsboys' Boycott Over"], ''New York Tribune''. 2 August 1899.</ref>
== Strike Leaders == The leadership of the newsboy strike was less centralized than most unions, with boys in each neighborhood feeling more loyalty to the other kids in their area than to the centralized leadership.<ref name=":0" /> That said, some kids were more influential than others, organizing rallies, acting as spokespeople for the strike, and being interviewed by papers such as the ''[[New-York Tribune|New York Tribune]]'', ''[[The New York Sun|New York Sun]]'' or ''[[New York Herald]]''. The papers often quoted the strikers with their New York accents depicted as an [[eye dialect]], using such sayings as "Me nobul men is all loyal."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/july-23-1899/|title=July 23, 1899: “Newsboys’ Word Stands”|date=2013-02-11|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Louis "Kid Blink" Baletti === The face of the strike was Louis "Kid Blink" Baletti. Kid Blink was 18 during the strike,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/137547362/louis-balletti|title=Louis “Kid Wink” Balletti (1883-1913) - Find A...|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref> and is described by papers at the time as an "undersized boy"<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-times/july-25-1899/|title=July 25, 1899: “Newsboys Act and Talk”|date=2013-02-11|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> with red hair and an eye patch over his left eye.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-23-1899/|title=July 23, 1899: “Newsboys’ Strike Swells”|date=2013-02-14|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> He also went by the nicknames "Red Blink",<ref name=":3" /> "Muggsy McGee"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-20-1899/|title=July 20, 1899: “Newsboys Strike Against Two Papers”|date=2015-03-01|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> and "Blind Diamond."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/july-24-1899/|title=July 24, 1899: “A Newsboys’ Meeting”|date=2013-02-11|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
Kid Blink was a charismatic leader. Several newspapers recorded speeches he gave at rallies, one of which reads in part "Friens and feller workers. This is a time which tries de hearts of men. Dis is de time when we'se got to stick together like glue.... We know wot we wants and we'll git it even if we is blind."<ref>(nd) [http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/database/article_display.cfm?HHID=166 Progressive Era: Newsies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205023702/http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/database/article_display.cfm?HHID=166 |date=2007-02-05 }}. Digital History. Retrieved 17 June 2007.</ref> His speech at the Irving Hall rally won him a floral horseshoe for the best speech of the evening.
Kid Blink was accused of betraying the strike and accepting a bribe to sell the boycotted papers, and though some sources claim he was acquitted of these charges he still stepped down from his leadership position after being accused.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/july-27-1899a/|title=July 27, 1899: “Tried for High Treason”|date=2013-02-27|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
When he was arrested during the strike, Kid Blink told the police his name was Louis Ballat,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-28-1899a/|title=July 28, 1899: “Newsboys Get New Leaders”|date=2013-04-04|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> but he was likely lying or misheard because his real name appears to have been Louis Baletti.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newsieshistory.tumblr.com/post/91454605563/some-things-we-know-about-the-real-kid-blink-part|title=Some things we know about the real Kid Blink, part one.|website=Newsies Historical Research|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
After the strike, Kid Blink got a job as a cart driver and later as a saloon keeper. He may have also worked as the right-hand man to New York mobster Chuck Connors. He died in July of 1913 at the age of 32 of tuberculosis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newsboys-of-1899.tumblr.com/post/179689207126/a-timeline-of-kid-blinks-life|title=A Timeline of Kid Blink’s Life|website=Newsies of 1899|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
=== David Simmons === David Simmons was president of the newsboy union at the beginning of the strike, and treasurer in the second half after he was accused of betraying the strike and was forced to step back from his leadership role.<ref name=":4" /> He was twenty-one at the time of the strike, and had been selling newspapers since the age of eight. He was also a well-known amateur prize fighter at the local athletic clubs.<ref name=":2" />
Simmons read a list of resolutions at the rally at Irving Hall, which the crowd reportedly found quite boring.<ref name=":1" />
=== Ed "Racetrack" Higgins === Ed "Racetrack" Higgins <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/july-31-1899/|title=July 31: “Striking Newsboys Elect Officers”date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> was the leader of the Brooklyn union, and was elected vice-president of the general union after Kid Blink and David Simmons stepped back.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-31-1899/|title=July 31, 1899: “Union to Enforce Newsboys’ Strike”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Higgins was a fixture at the [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]], and referenced horses in many quotes at the time of the strike.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newsboys-of-1899.tumblr.com/post/168014495741/race-track-higgins-and-his-wonderfully|title=“Race Track” Higgins and his wonderfully appropriate name|website=Newsboys of 1899|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
Higgins was a charismatic speaker, several papers mentioning his use of humour in his speeches to the striking newsboys. ''Brooklyn Life'' referred to him as "a born leader of boys, and he may yet be of men."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/2015/07/29/the-looker-on-racetrack-higgins/|title=“The Looker-On” Observing Racetrack Higgins|date=2015-07-29|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> His speech at the rally went off so well that the ''New York Times'' said that “If the newsboys present could have had a vote last night, “Race Track Higgins” could have had any office in their gift.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-times/july-25-1899/|title=July 25, 1899: “Newsboys Act and Talk”|date=2013-02-11|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Morris Cohen === Morris Cohen was union president after Kid Blink and David Simmons stepped down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/evening-telegram/july-27-1899/|title=July 27, 1899: “Salvation Lassies Wouldn’t Sell Them”|date=2015-03-31|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> Very little is known about him, but a July 20 memo from Joseph Pulitzer's business manager Don Seitz names Cohen as the boy who started the strike in New York City.<ref name=":0" />
=== Henry "Major Butts" Butler === Henry "Major Butts" Butler was leader of the Upper Manhattan union after Kid Blink stepped down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-herald/july-30-1899/|title=July 30, 1899: “Striking Newsboys Stand Firm”|date=2014-02-15|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> He was arrested on July 31, 1899 on a charge of blackmail after telling executives at the “New York World” that he would not break the strike for less than $600 ($600 in 1900, is roughly equivalent to $16,000 in 2018 with added inflation).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/sun/aug-1-1899/|title=August 1, 1899: “‘World’ Jails Newsboys”|date=2013-04-04|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Annie Kelly === Annie Kelly was one of the few newswomen loyal to the strike, a fact that made her very popular with the striking newsboys, who saw her as "almost a patron saint."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityhallpark1899.com/newspaper-articles/new-york-tribune/july-25-1899d/|title=July 25, 1899: “Park Row Capulets and Monatgues”|date=2013-02-12|work=City Hall Park 1899|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> She was the only woman to speak at the rally at Irving Hall, after being pulled on stage by a crowd of cheering newsboys, where she told them “All I can say, boys, is to stick together and we’ll win. That’s all I’ve got to say to you.”<ref name=":3" />
==Legacy== The newsboys' strike of 1899 has been credited with inspiring later strikes, including the [[Butte, Montana]], Newsboys Strike of 1914,<ref>Peavy, L. and Smith, U. (1999) ''Frontier Children.'' University of Oklahoma Press. p.112.</ref> and a 1920s strike in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].<ref>Reinier, J.S., Ferguson, P. and West, E. (2001) ''Boyhood in America: An encyclopedia.'' ABC-Clio Inc.</ref>
Some decades later, the introduction of urban [[Child protection|child-welfare]] practices led to improvements in the newsboys' quality of life.
==Cultural representations== The newsboys were fictionalized in 1942 by [[DC Comics]] as the [[Newsboy Legion]], first appearing in Issue number 7 of ''[[Star Spangled Comics]]'' and continuing therein through issue 64, as well as also continuing in various forms to modern-day comics.
The events of the 1899 strike later inspired the 1992 Disney film ''[[Newsies]]'', including a character named Kid Blink (who wears an eye patch), but in this version of the story the leader of the strike was named Jack Kelly. A [[musical theatre]] adaptation of the film, also called ''[[Newsies (musical)|Newsies]]'', debuted in 2011 and played on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] from 2012 to 2014, starring [[Jeremy Jordan (actor)|Jeremy Jordan]] as Jack Kelly, and on tour from 2014-2016. A live filmed version of the stage production with cast members from both the Broadway and Tour productions, was digitally released on May 23, 2017.
The newsboy strike is described in detail in the 2003 non-fiction book, ''[[Kids on Strike!]]''
== See also == {{Portal|Organized labour}} * ''[[NLRB v. Hearst Publications]]'' * [http://toto.lib.unca.edu/sr_papers/history_sr/srhistory_2010/hicks_greg.pdf An Uncivil War: The Newsboys' Strike of 1899]

revision.text: The '''Schweizeische Ausstellung für Frauenarbeit''' ('''SAFFA''', English: Swiss Exhibition for Women's Work) was an exhibition that took place in [[Bern]] in 1928 and in [[Zürich]] in 1958. SAFFA was organized by the [[Bund Schweizerischer Frauenvereine]] (BFS, the Federation of Swiss Women's Associations), the Swiss Catholic Women's League (SKF), and 28 other Swiss women's associations, to highlight the precarious situation of working women in the postwar years. == Saffa 1928 == [[File:Eigenheim Lux Guyer «Sunnebüel», Am Itschnacherstich 1 in Küsnacht 2011-08-26 14-19-28 ShiftN.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Lux Guyer]]'s ''SAFFAhaus'', as of today in Küsnacht]] The predecessor of Saffa was the first exhibition on women's work, organized by [[Rosa Neuenschwander]] in [[Bern]] in 1923.{{cite web|url=http://www.frauennet.ch/index.php/frauen-bewegung/21-saffa-1928-und-1958|title=Mutige Manifestation der Frauen: Die SAFFA 1928|website=frauennet.ch|language=german}}{{cite magazine|language=french|title=La vie de Rosa Neuenschwander (PDF)|magazine=Femmes Suisses et le mouvement féministe|issue=51|year=1963|url=http://www.e-periodica.ch/cntmng?pid=emi-002:1963:51::65}} In the '"Viererfeld" area (today Länggasse-Felsenau) in Bern, the first Saffa was held from 26 August until 30 September 1928. [[Lux Guyer|Louise (Lux) Guyer]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D9326.php|title=9326|publisher=HDS|author=Dagmar Böcker|language=German|date=2006-03-10|accessdate=2014-12-01}} the first Swiss women architect, was the chief organizator, and she completed the buildings in only three months using prefabricated elements made of wood.{{cite web|url=http://www.saffahaus.ch/|title=SAFFAhaus|publisher=saffahaus.ch|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2014-12-01}} When the fair opened, her reputation was firmly established. Focus of the exhibition were the services of women in family, working life, science and art; the representation of women's work and their importance for the Swiss economy and society. Saffa also promoted the female self-confidence and campaigned –for the so far not related – political rights to the Swiss women and the right to a gainful employment, as well as for their recognition as Swiss citizens with all political rights,{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D17336.php|title=Saffa|publisher=HDS|author=Yvonne Voegeli|language=German|date=2011-12-09|accessdate=2014-12-01}} unless the Women's suffrage in Switzerland was realized in the last cantons in 1990. == Saffa 1958 == [[File:Saffa-Insel - Zürichsee in Zürich - Landiwiese 2015-05-06 14-26-41.JPG|thumb|upright|''[[Saffa-Insel]]'' on [[Zürichsee]] lakeshore in Wollishofen]] From 17 July until 15 September 1958, the BSF led the second Saffa with over a hundred national and cantonal women's organisations on the ''[[Landiwiese]]'' in Zürich-[[Wollishofen]]. Before, the ''[[Saffa-Insel]]'', an artificial island was poured, being still a popular meeting place that is also used as lido in the summer and for events. As chief architect of the exhibition, which stood under the motto "Life circle of women in family, occupation, and country", acted Annemarie Hubacher-Constam.{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D27366.php|title=Hubacher [-Constam], Annemarie|publisher=HDS|author=Dagmar Böcker|language=German|date=2012-08-27|accessdate=2014-12-01}} SAFFA presented the women, who were wanted in the booming economy as consumers and workers, possibilities in the areas of education, employment, shopping and leisure. In accordance with the needs of economic and sociopolitical needs, SAFFA promoted the then three-phase model as an 'ideal female curriculum': employment prior to the marriage, motherhood, and return to the labour market. In addition, the women had to absorb negative impacts of the rapidly changing world, nevertheless, by spreading harmony inside and outside of their families. The men should be made aware of 'women services' in the service of the general public on the indispensability and so motivated to fix the social discrimination against women. With the profits from the two exhibitions, solidarity works were established for women. Having 1.9 million visitors, the exhibition was organized exclusively and also designed by women, including [[ETH Zurich]] alumnae [[Berta Rahm]] and Claire Rufer-Eckmann.Jakob, Evelyne Lang. "The Life and Work of Berta Rahm, 1910 - 1998," IAWA Newsletter, Fall 1999, V. 11, p. 1. {{cite web|url=http://spec.lib.vt.edu/IAWA/news/news11.pdf|title=Berta Rahm and Clair Rufer|accessdate=2018-03-28}}{{cite web|title=Berta Rahm|url=http://www.frauennet.ch/index.php/frauen-geschichten/8-berta-rahm|website=Frauennet|accessdate=28 March 2018}} An innovation and particularly startling were the [[Rotunda (architecture)|rotundas]], which were planned as manifestation of the solidarity of women. Topics such as "my home – my world", "needle and thread" and "in the realm of the kitchen" attracted the then housewives. The Saffa 1958 was marked by the upcoming vote to women's suffrage, thus the promoters did not practice an overly combative appearance and even created a "men paradise" (''Männerparadies'') department.{{cite web|url=http://www.stiftung-frauenarbeit.ch/index.php/de/stiftung/geschichte/ausstellungen|title=Die Ausstellungen|publisher=stiftung-frauenarbeit.ch|author=|language=|date=|accessdate=2014-12-04}} On occasion of the ''Saffatheater'' [[Jörg Schneider]] played in the cabaret comedy ''Lysistrata''.{{cite web|url=http://www.zol.ch/bezirk-hinwil/wetzikon/joerg-schneider-ist-tot/story/13778801|title=Jörg Schneider ist tot|publisher=[[Zürcher Oberländer]]|author=|language=German|date=2015-08-22|accessdate=2015-08-22}} For that time, the women excelled with innovative ideas, among the Saffa Women's Orchestra at the opening concert, of course, exclusively from women musicians, and directed by the first women conductor who graduated in Switzerland, [[Hedi Salquin]], who conducted the concerto for orchestra ''Intrada'' by [[Fernande Peyrot]] (1888–1978) in the [[Wasserkirche]] auditorium. The exhibition was a great success and generated a substantial financial surplus that was used for solidarity associations for women. The Saffa island was dedicated to women, and is part of the water lot owned by the canton of Zürich.{{cite web|url=http://www.frauennet.ch/index.php/frauen-bewegung/20-saffa-schweizerische-ausstellung-fuer-frauenarbeit|title=Die SAFFA – Schweizerische Ausstellung für Frauenarbeit|publisher=frauennet.ch|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2014-12-04}} == Saffa 2020 == The Swiss Federal Council signed the optional protocol as an addition to the Women Convention for the legal and formal recognition of the full human rights of women in Switzerland in February 2007. The Internet platform ''frauennet.ch'' proposed the decision to organise a third SAFFA on the occasion of their women picnic brunches on the Swiss national holiday on the ''Saffa-Island'' in Zürich. For financial reasons, the project could not be started for the time being. [[Alliance F]], as before better known as [[Bund Schweizerischer Frauenvereine]] (BFS), prepares a third Saffa, founded the "2020" association for this purpose, and initiated the project "2020 – der weibliche blick auf die zukunft" (literally: 2020 – the female looks to the future). The project seeks to capture ideas and visions for the future of our society from the perspective of women and in an appropriate manner of the public present. A first web presentation was 2013 and started the realization phase to SAFFA 2020. The project ''2020 – der weibliche blick auf die zukunft'' is under the patronage of the three federal councillors (''Bundesrat'') [[Doris Leuthard]], [[Simonetta Sommaruga]] and [[Eveline Widmer-Schlumpf]] as well as by the former councillor (''aBR'') [[Micheline Calmy-Rey]].{{cite web|url=http://www.2020.ch/site/?page_id=13=|title=Patronat|publisher=2020.ch|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2014-12-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223701/http://www.2020.ch/site/?page_id=13%3D|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}} == See also == * [[Bund Schweizerischer Frauenvereine]] (BFS) * [[Women's suffrage in Switzerland]] == Literature == * Sibylle Brändli: ''Der Supermarkt im Kopf: Konsumkultur und Wohlstand in der Schweiz nach 1945.'' Böhlau Verlag, Wien 2000, {{ISBN|9783205992646}}. * Marie-Louise Barben, Elisabeth Ryter: ''Verflixt und zugenähnt. Frauenberufsbildung - Frauenerwerbsarbeit 1888 - 1988''. Bern 1988, {{ISBN|9783905278330}}. * M. Beyeler: ''La SAFFA (Schweiz. Ausstellung für Frauenarbeit) de 1958 à Zurich: son architecture et ses architectes''. Dissertation, Lausanne 1999. * Dorothee Huber: ''Die Tugend der Not. Zu den beiden historischen Ausstellungen für Frauenarbeit (SAFFA 1928 und 1958)''. In: ''Ausstellungen - Darstellungen, Beiträge zum Diplomwahlfach "Frauen in der Geschichte des Bauens"'', Vol. 3, Petra Stojanik (pbl), Lehrstuhl Flora Ruchat-Roncati ETHZ, Zürich 1995. == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commons category|Saffa-Insel}} * {{HDS|17336|Saffa|author=Yvonne Voegeli|date=9 December 2011}} * [http://www.alliancef.ch/ alliance F] {{de icon}} {{fr icon}} * [http://www.stiftung-frauenarbeit.ch/ Stiftung für Erforschung der Frauenarbeit] {{de icon}} {{fr icon}} {{it icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091004092545/http://www1.2020.ch/ ''2020 – Der weibliche Blick auf die Zukunft''] {{de icon}} {{fr icon}} [[Category:Women's history]] [[Category:Exhibitions]] [[Category:Culture in Bern]] [[Category:Culture of Zürich]] [[Category:History of Bern]] [[Category:History of Zürich]] [[Category:1928 in Switzerland]] [[Category:1958 in Switzerland]] [[Category:2020 in Switzerland]] [[Category:Feminism]] [[Category:Swiss society]] [[Category:Women's rights in Switzerland]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Switzerland]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} {{Sri Aurobindo}} '''Satprem''' (30 October 1923 – 9 April 2007) was a French author and a disciple of [[Mirra Alfassa]]. ==Early life== Satprem was born Bernard Enginger in [[Paris]] and had a seafaring childhood and youth in [[Brittany]]. During World War II he was a member of the [[French Resistance]] (in the "[[Turma-Vengeance]]" network). He was arrested by the [[Gestapo]] in late 1943 and spent one and a half years in German [[concentration camp]]s. Scarred by the experience, after the war he became interested in the [[existentialism]] of [[André Gide]] and [[André Malraux]].Georges van Vrekham, ''Beyond the Human Species'' p.370 ==India== He travelled to [[Egypt]] and then [[India]], where he worked briefly as a [[civil servant]] in the French colonial administration of [[Puducherry|Pondicherry]], on the [[Bay of Bengal]]. There he discovered [[Sri Aurobindo]] and [[Mira Alfassa|The Mother]] and their "new evolution". He resigned from the civil service, and went in search of adventure in [[French Guiana]], where he spent a year in the [[Amazon Rainforest|Amazon]] (the setting for his first novel ''L'Orpailleur'' (''The Gold Washer''), with his copy of Sri Aurobindo's ''[[The Life Divine]]'', then [[Brazil]], and after that [[Africa]]. In 1953, aged 30, he returned to India and [[Pondicherry (city)|Pondicherry]] to put himself at the service of The Mother and settle in the [[Ashram]]. He taught a little at the Ashram school, and was in charge of the French copy for the quarterly ''Bulletin of the Department of Physical Education'' which was The Mother's publication, and is still printed in English and French. During this time he met his companion [[Sujata Nahar]]. Enginger then travelled once more throughout the [[Congo (area)|Congo]], Brasília, [[Afghanistan]], the Himalayas, [[New Zealand]], and sailed around the world, before once again returning. On 3 March 1957, The Mother gave him the name Satprem ("the one who loves truly").''Agenda'' vol.1, p.48 n.2, and p.100 Satprem remained restless and dissatisfied for some years, torn between his devotion to The Mother along with Sri Aurobindo's teachings, and his wanderlust, and in 1959 he again left the ashram. He became the disciple of a [[Vajrayana|Tantric]] lama, a priest of temple at [[Rameswaram]]. Then as the disciple of another Yogi he spent six months wandering around India as a mendicant [[sanyasi]] practicing Tantra, which formed the basis of his second novel, ''Par le Corps de la Terre, ou le Sanyassin'' (''By the Body of the Earth or, The Sanyasi'').''Beyond the Human Species'' p.371 After this he returned again (as he put it, "the bird flew back once more" ''[[Mother's Agenda]]'' vol.1 p.327), to the Pondicherry Ashram and the Mother, who started inviting him from time to time to her room, originally for work in connection with the Bulletin. As their relationship developed, he asked more questions, and eventually decided to record their conversations, taking a tape-recorder to her room. The result of this collaboration was the 13-volume ''The Agenda'', the first of which covers 1951 to 1960 (and contains Satprem's letters to The Mother during his wandering days), and ends with the year 1973. 90% of the volumes consists of the Mother's explanation of her inner and outer experiences, with Satprem's comments, questions for her, etc. A great deal of the conversation involved Mother's discussions of how she was trying to make her physical body open to what she believed was a spiritual force, so illness and death could be overcome, not only for herself, but for humanity. Also, under The Mother's guidance he wrote ''Sri Aurobindo, ou l'Aventure de la Conscience'' (''Sri Aurobindo, or the Adventure of Consciousness''), which became the most popular introductory book to Sri Aurobindo and The Mother (published 1964). In 1972 and 1973 he also wrote under the Mother's guidance the essay ''La Genèse du Surhomme'' (''On the Way to Supermanhood''), which she regarded very highly. This was published in 1974. ==Death of the Mother== Satprem relates that on 19 May 1973, six months before The Mother's death he was barred admission to her room,Satprem Mind of the Cells'', 1982 p.200, and ''Agenda'' vol.13 the beginning of a serious falling out between the [[Sri Aurobindo Ashram|Ashram]] leadership and himself. Moreover, Satprem and his followers believe there is evidence in the recorded audiotapes that the Mother did not actually die but rather entered a "cataleptic trance" or state of suspended animation in which there would not even be a detectable heartbeat.''Mind of the Cells'' pp.198-202 Satprem recorded a famous conversation between the Mother and Pranab which made Satprem conclude that several Ashram sadhaks did not want the Mother to continue her life. However, Pranab has argued that on the contrary he was very much concerned about the Mother's health and that he had received precise instructions from her as to what to do when she appeared to have left her body.Pranab Kumar Bhattacharya, ''I Remember'', Sri Aurobindo Bhavan, Calcutta 1993, pp.132-133 These instructions, he says, were exactly followed before she was buried in the second chamber of Sri Aurobindo's Samadhi in the Ashram courtyard under the Service tree, which she herself got prepared after Sri Aurobindo's departure in December 1950. Georges Van Vrekhem disagrees with Satprem's claim that the Mother's work was cut short in those last six months, and argues instead that she did indeed attain a [[Supermind (Integral thought)|Supramental body]] and what remained was the residue, like the empty cocoon of a caterpillar after it has become a butterfly Van Vrekhem, ''Beyond the Human Species'' pp.496ff. ==Writing and publishing== After the Mother's death, all of Satprem's correspondence from 1962 to 1973 with the Mother was confiscated, and he fled with the tapes of the Agenda to [[Auroville]], where, at the age of 50, he edited the 13 volumes of the Agenda, while at the same time wrote the trilogy ''Mère'' (''Mother'') - ''Le Matérialisme Divin'' (''The Divine Materialism''), ''L'Espèce Nouvelle'' (''The New Species''), ''La Mutation de la Mort'' (''The Mutation of Death'') - both a biography of the Mother and his own analyses and commentary on the Agenda material. Satprem became a rallying point for the community shocked by the attitude the ashram leaders had taken.Savitra, "When Intensity overtakes Integrality; a personal look at the man and the myth called Satprem", ''NexUS, the newsletter for the USA Centres of Sri Aurobindo and the Mother'' Winter 1994-95, pp.27-30 His one-man revolt against the Ashram leadership began in 1974, and involved two issues. One was his wish to publish, unexpurgated, the entire transcript of his talks with the Mother. He saw the resistance of the ashram trustees and elders in this regard as symptomatic of the way they had directed the ashram from 1962 onwards. The other was his claim that under the current leadership the Yoga had become institutionalised and dogmatic, like the yogas of the past. For their part, the elders wished to publish the transcripts but only in edited form. And where Satprem saw conservatism and dogmatism, they saw a loyal commitment to their gurus to uphold the original truth of their teachingsDavid J. Lorenzo, ''Tradition and the Rhetoric of Right'' p.223-5 During this time, Satprem was looked to by the French-speaking Aurovillians as the successor and inheritor of Sri Aurobindo and the Mother's work, and a number of radicals were drawn to him because of his revolt against the Ashram elders ''Tradition and the Rhetoric of Right'' p.223 After numerous unsuccessful attempts to get the 13 volumes of the Agenda published by the Ashram, Auroville, and Sri Aurobindo Society presses, Satprem founded the ''Institut de Recherches Évolutives'' (Institute for Evolutionary Research) in Paris in July 1977 as a non-profit organisation to do so.".Robert Minor, ''The Religious, the Spiritual, and the Secular'' p.177 note 4 Soon after, there was an allegation of an assassination attempt against him in August 1976, and in December 1977 (or 1978) the Ashram trustees "expelled" him for "anti-ashram activities" as he attempted to publish the ''Agenda'', and he became ''persona non grata'' in the Ashram.[[Richard Titlebaum]] (1985-1986) {{cite web |url=http://www.rtitlebaum.com/TheMother.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018031815/http://www.rtitlebaum.com/TheMother.html |archivedate=2007-10-18 |df= }} "Commentary" From The Journals, Boston, MA, 1985-1986 Satprem and Sujata left [[Puducherry]] in 1978. In 1980 Satprem wrote ''Le Mental des Cellules'' (''The Mind of the Cells''), a synopsis and introduction of the whole Agenda, focusing on the Mother's attempt to make the cells responsive to a supramental Force so their inner programming could be altered so not to automatically fall into illness, decay, and death, which was the ultimate physical result of Sri Aurobindo's Integral (Purna) Yoga. In 1982 all 13 volumes of the ''Agenda'' were published in French, and Satprem felt he had completed all his external work.Luc Venet ''Life without Death'', p.113 The following year, he and Sujata decided to withdraw completely from public life to devote themselves exclusively to Sri Aurobindo's and Mother's work of the transformation of the cellular consciousness of the [[Human body|body]] and realisation of the new evolution, and the search for the "great passage" in the evolution beyond Man. The 1985 book ''La Vie sans Mort'' (''Life without Death'') is a follow-up to ''Mind of the Cells'', co-written with Luc Venet,For an indepth description of Luc Venet's 20-year experience of closely collaborating with Satprem, see his essay on http://www.lesyeuxouverts.net and provides a glimpse of Satprem in his post-Ashram life in this period.''Life without Death'', Part 3: Satprem (pp.107ff.) After seven years, Satprem emerged and began producing a steady stream of books on his experiences, Sri Aurobindo and the Mother's teachings, and the future evolution of Man. In 1989, he wrote ''La Révolte de la Terre'' (''The Revolt of the Earth''), in which he describes his years "digging" in the body. This was followed in 1992 by ''Evolution II'', where he asks "After Man, who? But the question is: After Man, how?" In 1994 came his ''Lettres d'un Insoumis'' (''Letters of a Rebel''), two volumes of autobiographical correspondence. In 1995 he wrote ''La Tragédie de la Terre - de Sophocle à Sri Aurobindo'' (''The Tragedy of the Earth - from Sophocles to Sri Aurobindo''), an urgent message for mankind to take action against the cycle of death. This was followed in 1998 by ''La Clef des Contes'' (''The Key of Tales''), and in 1999 by "Néanderthal Regarde'' (''Neanderthal Looks On''), an essay on the betrayal of Man in India as in the West. In 2000 followed ''La Légende de l'Avenir'' (''The Legend of the Future'') and in 2002 ''Mémoires d'un Patagonien - Conte Préhistorique et Posthistorique'' (''Memoires of a Patagonian - Prehistoric and Posthistoric Tale'') and ''La Philosophie de l'Amour'' (''The Philosophy of Love''). In 2008, the IRE published his last book, ''L'Oiseau Doël'' (''The Doël Bird'').
In 1999, Satprem also started the publication of his ''Carnets d'un Apocalypse'' (''Notebooks of an Apocalypse'') (in French, seven volumes published to date, in English only vol.1, 1973-1978, dealing with the years and his experiences immediately after the passing of the Mother), which records his work in the depths of the body consciousness.http://www.ire-miraditi.org/miraditi/sat-suj.html "Satprem and Sujata" ==Death== Satprem died on April 9, 2007 at the age of 83. His companion Sujata Nahar died after him on May 4, 2007. ==Partial bibliography== * Satprem (1964) (2000, 2nd edition) ''Sri Aurobindo or the Adventure of Consciousness'' Mira Aditi, Mysore, & The Mother's Institute of Research, New Delhi * Satprem (ed.) ''[[Mother's Agenda]]'' (1982) Institut de Recherches Evolutives, Paris, & Mira Aditi, Mysore (13 vol set) * Satprem (1982, 1999) ''The Mind of the Cells'' Institut de Recherches Evolutives, Paris, & Mira Aditi, Mysore * Satprem (2002) ''On the Way to Supermanhood'' Mira Aditi, Mysore, & The Mother's Institute of Research, New Delhi * Satprem (1992), ''Evolution II'' Institut de Recherches Evolutives, Paris, & Mira Aditi, Mysore * Satprem (1998), ''The Revolt of the Earth'' Institut de Recherches Evolutives, Paris, & Mira Aditi, Mysore * Satprem (1998), ''The Tragedy of the Earth'' Institut de Recherches Evolutives, Paris, & Mira Aditi, Mysore * Satprem (1981), ''My Burning Heart'', Ingram, Tennessee ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * ''Mother's Agenda'' (1979-??) (Engl. transl) Institute for Evolutionary Research, New York, NY (13 vol set) * David J. Lorenzo, ''Tradition and the Rhetoric of Right: Popular Political Argument in the Aurobindo Movement'', Fairleigh Dickinson University Press, 1999 {{ISBN|0-8386-3815-5}} * Robert N. Minor, ''The Religious, the Spiritual, and the Secular: Auroville and Secular India'', SUNY Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-7914-3991-7}} * Satprem (1982) ''The Mind of the Cells'' Institute for Evolutionary Research, New York, NY {{ISBN|0-938710-06-0}} * Georges van Vrekhem, ''Beyond the Human Species'' Paragon House, St Paul, Minnesota, 1998 {{ISBN|978-1-55778-766-8}} (first published in Dutch 1995) * Luc Venet (1985) ''Life without Death'', Institute for Evolutionary Research, New York, NY {{ISBN|0-938710-23-0}} *Elfi, Nicole (1998). Satprem, par un fil de lumière: Biographie. Paris: R. Laffont. ==External links== * [http://www.aurobindo.ru/workings/ma/index_e.htm#02 Agenda (with audiorecords by Satprem). Texts in French, English, German and Russian] * [http://www.aurobindo.ru/persons/00129_e.htm About Satprem; his workings (full texts); photos, video and audio] * [http://intyoga.online.fr/bio_vrek.htm Satprem] as seen by [[Georges van Vrekhem]] in ''Beyond the Human Species'' Chapter 23 "Two Rooms" pages 370-373 {{Integral Yoga|state=expanded}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Converts to Hinduism]] [[Category:French expatriates in Brazil]] [[Category:French expatriates in India]] [[Category:People of French India]] [[Category:New religious movements]] [[Category:People from Paris]] [[Category:Sri Aurobindo]]
